p.span:
The SPEAKER ( Hon.
Tony Smith ) took the chair at 10:00, made an acknowledgement of country and read prayers.
COMMITTEES
Petitions Committee
Report
Mrs WICKS (Robertson) (10:01): Today I present the 33rd report of the Petitions Committee for the 45th Parliament.
PETITIONS
Mrs WICKS (Robertson) (10:01): I present the following two petitions:
Australian Broadcasting Corporation

This petition of certain concerned citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House that the ABC's independence is integral to Australia's democracy. ABC Chair Justin Milne trying to get rid of journalists who were critical of government policy, and interfering in ABC editorial policy in response to government pressure, is completely unacceptable.

We therefore ask the House to ensure that the Minister for Communications replaces Justin Milne by a chair who is truly independent of government. We also ask the House to ensure that the ABC is free from any and all political interference and fully funded, so it can continue to deliver fearless reporting to the public.
from 244 citizens (Petition No. PN0384)

subdebateinfo.title: Bass Strait Passenger Vehicle Equalisation Scheme

p.span: Bass Strait Passenger Vehicle Equalisation Scheme

TO THE HONOURABLE THE SPEAKER AND MEMBERS OF THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES This petition, by Peter Brohier, draws attention of the House to: The ferry link on our national highway network, supported by the Coalition's Bass Strait Passenger Vehicle Equalisation Scheme, 'BSPVES', was to deliver highway equalized transport for people crossing Bass Strait. Prime Minister Keating suggested Tasmania use 'its natural and developed strengths' instead of approaching Canberra for subsidies. At the time, the Howard and Keating solutions aimed to deliver affordable 'highway equivalence' by ferry, and maximize use of these strengths. Each had different ways of achieving the same result. The BSPVES now needs urgent adjustment to meet its initial objective. The social and economic consequences of not restoring the BSPVES and breaking rare bipartisan support over this vital national transport link are severe. Bass Strait transport equality is a Federal responsibility. It should not be delegated or adjusted to meet the wants of any interest group, individual state government, nor turned into subsidies or political footballs. Moves against 'equalisation' separate the nation and erode our federation. They savagely restrict the movement of people between inter-dependent state economies. They replace the certain basis of critical equalisation schemes, with uncertainty. They act contrary to democratic processes. Ongoing bipartisan and transparent policy should apply across such a critical link.

I therefore request the House call on the Prime Minister and Leader of the Opposition to confirm whether they intend to continue a bipartisan position supporting equalized transport of people, as announced by Prime Minister's Keating and Howard, and as they do for freight.
from 1 citizen (Petition No. PN0387)
Petitions received.
PETITIONS
Responses
Mrs WICKS (Robertson) (10:01): I present 19 ministerial responses to petitions previously presented:
Medical Workforce
Dear Mrs Wicks

Thank you for your letter of 6 February 2018 to the Minister of Health, The Hon Greg Hunt, MP concerning the petition presented to the Standing Committee on Petitions concerning the reclassification of Deniliquin as a District of Workforce Shortage. This matter has been referred to me as the Minister for Regional Services, Minister for Sport and Minister for Local Government and Decentralisation with portfolio responsibility for this matter. My sincere apologies for the delay in responding.

I note the issues raised in the petition, in particular, concerns with relieving the rural health workforce shortage in Deniliquin. The District of Workforce Shortage system is an impartial mechanism used by the Liberal National Government to encourage a more equitable distribution of medical services across Australia. The District of Workforce Shortage system identifies geographic areas in which the population has less access to Medicare subsidised health services when compared to the national average. This calculation is based on the services provided and not just the number of medical practitioners. As such the Department of Health can consider doctors who work part-time in the area.

The methodology by which an area is determined to be a District of Workforce Shortage is provided in the legislative instrument Health Insurance (Section 19AB Exemptions) Guidelines, which does not allow for discretionary determinations. However, there are provisions for 19AB restricted doctors to work as locums for up to six months in non-District of Workforce Shortage areas. For further information on these provisions please contact the Department of Health via 19AB@health.gov.au.

Deniliquin is currently not classified as a District of Workforce Shortage as it is in an assessment area with a better population-to-GP ratio than the Australian average. This measure also includes Medicare Benefits Schedule billing information to capture GP activity in an area. While I note the difficulties you have outlined regarding recruitment, patients in Deniliquin still have better access to medical services compared to the national average.

The Liberal National Government established a Distribution Working Group to review the use of the District of Workforce Shortage and other geographical classification systems and make recommendations for improvement. The Group is assessing several measures that may be considered against the current District of Workforce Shortage model and is due to provide their recommendations by the end of the year.

The General Practice Rural Incentives Program encourages medical practitioners to practice in regional and remote communities through the provision of financial incentives. The General Practice Rural Incentives Program supports medical practitioners who provide eligible services in the smaller and more remote communities in Australia. Under this program, a doctor working in Deniliquin can receive an incentive of up to $18,000 per year.

Through the Rural Health Multidisciplinary Training program, the Liberal National Government is providing funding designed to encourage the recruitment and retention of rural and remote health professionals by supporting universities to deliver effective rural clinical training experiences to medical, dental, nursing and allied health students.

Additionally, the Liberal National Government funds a network of seven Rural Workforce Agencies in each state to assist communities that experience difficulties in attracting and retaining health professionals who may be able to assist in recruitment strategies. The Rural Workforce Agency in New South Wales is the NSW Rural Doctors Network and they can be contacted by telephoning (02) 4924 8000, or via their website at www.rswrdn.com.au.

In the 2018-19 Budget, the Liberal National Government announced the Stronger Rural Health Strategy (the Strategy), a carefully calibrated suite of measures to address each stage of medical workforce supply - teaching, training and retention. It is a historic 10-year plan to meet current and future health workforce challenges and it supports the largest overhaul of Australia's health workforce in decades. The Strategy will deliver a comprehensive package of reforms in a $550 million investment over five years from 2017-18. This will provide all Australians with the right mix of qualified health professionals in the right place, at the right time to deliver high quality health care. It includes a range of incentives, targeted funding and bonding arrangements to meet head-on the challenge of redistributing the workforce across regional, rural and remote Australia, beyond the cities and metropolitan areas.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
from the Minister for Regional Services, Minister for Sport, Minister for Local Government and Decentralisation, Senator the Hon Bridget McKenzie. (Petition No. PN0204)
cc. The Hon Greg Hunt MP. Minister for Health
Live Animal Exports
Dear Mrs Wicks

Thank you for your letter of 17 September 2018 regarding petition PN0368. I appreciate the views of the signatories on the petition on the live export trade and I note their concerns about the treatment of exported animals.

The Coalition Government supports a sustainable livestock export trade and is taking action to improve animal welfare standards and make the trade more accountable for its actions. I do not support a phasing out of the Australian live animal export industry. However, what I saw in the footage horrified me. Animal cruelty is abhorrent and must be condemned and so I have swiftly responded to the issues that have recently come to light.

The government supported the recommendations of the independent review into live sheep exports to the Middle East in the northern summer, which was conducted by veterinarian Dr Michael McCarthy. The review's recommendations are being implemented as a priority, including further work on livestock heat stress risk assessment. Dr McCarthy's report and the government's response can be found on the Department of Agriculture and Water Resources' website at https://agriculture.gov.au/LAE.
An issues paper on an approach to heat stress risk assessment of livestock for export to the Middle
East is on the Department's 'Have Your Say' web page at https://haveyoursay.agriculture.gov.au/hsra-review.

Dr McCarthy's recommendations build on Australia's existing livestock export assurance systems, including the Australian Standards for the Export of Livestock (ASEL) and Exporter Supply Chain Assurance System (ESCAS). The ASEL ensures that livestock are fit for export and that their health and welfare are managed during live export voyages. An independent technical committee is currently reviewing the ASEL and has released a stage two draft for public consultation until 27 November. More information and opportunity to comment on the ASEL review is available at http://agriculture.gov.au/animal/welfare/export-trade/review-asel.

In April 2018, I commissioned Mr Philip Moss AM to review the capability, culture and investigative powers of the department as the regulator of live exports. On 31 October 2018, I announced the government's intent to appoint an external, independent Inspector General of Live Animal Exports who will oversee the department's regulation of live export and report to the public and the Minister and the creation of a Principal Regulatory Officer within the department to improve regulatory practice, compliance and its culture as regulator.

Further to this, the department will establish an animal welfare branch which will develop animal welfare indicators to be used as part of compliance systems in addition to other export trade related work. The new on-vessel independent observer and equivalency program will improve monitoring and assessment of the performance of exporters.
A copy of the Moss Report, the Government and departmental responses are available at http://www.agriculture.gov.au/animal/welfare/export-trade/independent-review-of-regulation.

Importantly, the department will also improve its governance system to allow concerns (including those over live animal exports) raised by staff members to be addressed transparently and promptly. We expect witnesses of bad behaviour in the trade to call the new Whistleblower Hotline (1800 319 595) between 07.00-19.00 on weekdays where they can anonymously report their concerns.

For the trade to continue, exporters must meet their responsibilities and be accountable to the government and the community. There must be trust in the trade. The Government intends to present a Bill in Parliament to increase penalties for those who breach laws. The regulator has cancelled two export licences, demonstrating that where exporters are in the wrong, action will be taken. The outcomes of investigations into compliance and mortalities on live export voyages can be found at https://aariculture.gov.au/export/controlled-goods/live-animals/livestock/regulatoryÂ­framework/compliance-investigations.

The Coalition government remains absolutely committed to supporting our hard working farmers and regional communities who would be unfairly affected by a full ban on the trade. The actions outlined above are essential to address concerns held by the public and the government about animal welfare.
Thank you for raising your concerns about this important issue.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Agriculture and Water Resources, the Hon. David Littleproud MP (Petition No. PN0368)
Health
Dear Mrs Wicks

I refer to your letter of 25 October 2018 concerning petitions PN0380 and EN0709 presented in the House by the member for Lyne requesting me to exercise my discretionary power to approve a new pharmacy in Bonny Hills, New South Wales.

I can confirm that my Department has recently received a request, from a pharmacist, for the exercise of my discretionary power to approve the supply of Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS) medicines at pharmacy premises in Bonny Hills, New South Wales.
Legislation provides that I must decide whether or not to consider that request by 26 January 2019.

My Department will provide me with a submission, which includes the pharmacist's request for approval, correspondence received in relation to the request and research by my Department. These petitions will be included with that submission and I will consider them when making my decision.

My discretionary power is designed to address circumstances where there is an unintended consequence of the Pharmacy Location Rules. I can only exercise my discretionary power if I am satisfied that a decision to not approve a pharmacist would result in a community being left without reasonable access to PBS medicines, and it is in the public interest to do so.
Thank you for drawing these petitions to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health, the Hon Greg Hunt MP (Petition Nos PN0380 and EN0709)
Radioactive Waste Management
Dear Mrs Wicks

Thank you for referring PN0381 which outlined opposition to the siting of the National Radioactive Waste Management Facility (the Facility) on agricultural land in Kimba or South Australia. A copy of the referral letter is enclosed.

The waste to be securely managed in the new Facility is generated by nuclear medical and scientific activities that benefit all Australians. With these benefits comes a responsibility to manage this waste. A national Facility that is safe and purpose-built will bring together radioactive waste from more than 100 locations around the country and is specifically authorised under the Commonwealth National Radioactive Waste Management Act 2012 (the Act).

The petition requested that the House of Representatives remove both Kimba sites from the shortlist to host the Facility. The Australian Government has engaged in good faith with the Kimba community for more than 18 months and has committed to that community to see this process through. It is therefore not appropriate that these sites be removed from consideration at this time. That consultation, along with a public submissions process and technical studies of the sites, will inform whether or not one of these sites is selected for the Facility.

The petition also requested that the Government undertake a proper process to select a Facility site. The process that has been adopted by the Government is based on voluntary nominations, places each community at its centre and is consistent with practices adopted in many other countries also seeking to establish similar waste facilities. The process is deliberately designed to ensure all communities, including Aboriginal communities, have comprehensive information on the Facility and the process, and multiple opportunities to have their say.

The Senate Economics References Committee August 2018 report into the site selection process for the Facility acknowledged that it is a complex and difficult task and found no fundamental flaws in the process. The Government is considering the report and will respond to recommendations to improve the process. However, the approach undertaken by the Government is consistent with the Committee's recommendations.

The petition also specifically requested that the process locate a site that does not impact on agriculture, industry and social cohesion. Radioactive waste facilities and farms have succeeded side-by-side for decades, both in Australia and around the world, without any reputational or market impact on surrounding agriculture, tourism or other community activities. Internationally, where radioactive waste industries are located in agricultural regions, they play an important role in the life of local communities by providing jobs and investment, and strengthening local economic and social development.
Thank you for providing me with the opportunity to respond to this petition.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Resources and Northern Australia, Senator the Hon Matthew Canavan (Petition No. PN0381)
Energy: Light Bulbs
Dear Mrs Wicks
Thank you for your email to the former Minister for the Environment and Energy, the Hon Josh Frydenberg MP, concerning petition EN0590 on health effects of energy efficient lighting.

The phase-out of incandescent lighting commenced in 2009 to remove the least efficient light bulbs from the Australian market. It included the introduction of minimum standards to require compact fluorescent lamps and halogen light bulbs to meet a range of quality parameters. The Department of the Environment and Energy (the Department) estimates that the phase out of incandescent light bulbs is saving around 2.4 terawatt-hours of electricity each year, with cumulative national savings of $5.5 billion.

Prior to the phase-out, the Australian Government considered the potential health implications of this policy, drawing on international research and expertise in the field. The Department monitors research on the health effects of lighting and provides information on this topic at: www.energyrating.gov.au/products/lightingl. Visual discomfort may also result from the design of a lighting installation by the placement of light fixtures, illuminance levels, uniformity and glare, as well as by the qualities of the products installed.

On 20 April 2018, the COAG Energy Council agreed to improve lighting energy efficiency regulation by phasing out inefficient halogen light bulbs in Australia and introducing minimum standards for LED light bulbs in Australia and New Zealand, in line with European Union standards. LED bulbs are available in a wide range of colour temperatures, including bulbs that provide light in colour temperatures similar to incandescent and halogen lighting, and LED light bulbs are more energy efficient, than halogen or incandescent light bulbs. With the introduction of minimum standards for LED light bulbs, it is proposed to consider acceptable levels of flicker, to minimise the potential for problems from the greater use of LED lights.
Thank you for bring this petition to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for the Environment and Energy, the Hon Angus Taylor MP. (Petition No. EN0590)
Illicit Drugs
Dear Mrs Wicks

I refer to your letter of 18 June 2018 on behalf of the Standing Committee on Petitions, concerning the proposal to legalise cannabis for adult use - Petition Number EN0596. I regret the delay in responding.

The Australian Government's views on cannabis are consistent with the principles set out in Australia's National Drug Strategy, which identifies cannabis as a priority substance and outlines a range of evidence-based approaches to minimise harm associated with cannabis use. These approaches include preventing uptake and delaying first time use, providing access to a range of treatment, support and information services and the disruption in supply to reduce availability.

The potential harms associated with using cannabis can depend on the age of a person, pattern of use, other risky behaviours and other underlying health conditions. Key medical bodies including the Australian Medical Association and the Royal Australasian College of Physicians have repeatedly expressed concerns over the proposal to legalise cannabis.

While many Australians may view cannabis use as harmless, almost a quarter of Australia's drug and alcohol treatment services are being provided to people identifying cannabis as their principal drug of concern (roughly the same number of treatment episodes as for amphetamine use).

The Australian Government does not support legalising cannabis for recreational use but notes that issues relating to prohibition, legalisation, deregulation and decriminalisation of cannabis are primarily the responsibility of states and territories.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health, the Hon Greg Hunt MP (Petition No. EN0596)
Australian Constitution
Dear Mrs Wicks
Thank you for your letter of 13 August 2018 regarding petition number EN0615.

The petition concerns responsibility for the investigation and prosecution of suspected criminal wrongdoing relating to the provision of misleading citizenship information in the course of electoral nomination.

I note the petition requests the House of Representatives to determine the responsible body for prosecution of the alleged wrongdoing. The petition also requests examination of relevant reports of the alleged wrongdoing by the responsible person, department or authority, and that these matters are put to a court for a decision.

The petition asserts that "[t]he Australian Federal Police advised those who lodged the crime reports that reports of Commonwealth Crimes will be ignored in relation to false declaration on nomination forms." I am informed no such advice has been offered by the Australian Federal Police (AFP). The AFP is responsible for investigating offences against the Criminal Code Act 1995. Any person, including the Australian Electoral Commission (AEC), may make a report to the AFP if they have evidence of any offence. The AFP operates independently of Government and the decision whether or not to investigate an alleged offence is a matter for the AFP's discretion. It would not be appropriate for me or my department to intervene in such decisions.

The initiation and conduct of a prosecution is a matter for the Commonwealth Director of Public Prosecutions (CDPP) to determine in accordance with the Prosecution Policy of the Commonwealth. Once sufficient evidence has been gathered to substantiate a criminal charge, this evidence is compiled in a brief and referred to the CDPP. The CDPP is an independent statutory authority operating outside the political process.

The Australian Electoral Commission (AEC) is responsible for conducting federal elections and referendums and maintaining the Commonwealth electoral roll. It would be open to the AEC to refer any relevant conduct within its remit to the AFP for further investigation. However, the AEC is not responsible for investigating or prosecuting such offences.
I have written to the Special Minister of State, who has responsibility for electoral matters, to bring this petition to his attention.
Thank you for raising this matter with me.
Yours sincerely
from the Attorney-General, the Hon Christian Porter MP (Petition No. EN0615)
Economy
Dear Mrs Wicks

Thank you for your letter of 13 August 2018 concerning Petition EN0616 on the cash economy, in your capacity as Chair of the Standing Committee on Petitions. As this matter falls within my portfolio responsibilities, your correspondence has been referred to me for response. The delay in response is regretted.

The Government announced a range of new measures as part of the 2018-19 Budget to combat the black economy, including making cash payments over $10,000 to businesses illegal. This was in response to the recommendations made by the Black Economy Taskforce in its final report to Government. Transactions in excess of this amount would need to be made using the electronic payment system or by cheque.

In committing to implementing the $10,000 cash payment limit, the Government is seeking to strike the right balance between cracking down on black economy participants using large cash transactions to avoid their tax obligations, and ensuring that businesses doing the right thing are not unduly burdened by increased red tape.

The Government recognises that cash remains an important part of the economy and a legitimate means of payment for consumers and businesses particularly for lower value transactions while also noting a decline in the use of cash. Analysis by the Reserve Bank of Australia released in March 2017, highlighted the declining use of cash with only 37 per cent of payments made in cash in 2016 and a median cash transaction value of only $12.

The Government has also recently moved to combat illicit tobacco. From 1 July 2019, importers of tobacco will be required to pay all duty and tax liabilities upon importation. This is a change from the current system, where tobacco can be imported and stored in licensed warehouses prior to tax being paid.
Itrust this information is of assistance to the Petitions Committee.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Treasurer, the Hon Stuart Robert MP (Petition No. EN0616)
Child Support Act
Dear Mrs Wicks

Thank you for your letter dated 13 August 2018 to the former Minister for Social Services, the Hon Dan Tehan MP, regarding petition EN0630 to the House of Representatives about disputed care arrangements under the child support scheme.

The child support scheme is designed to ensure the financial support for children of separated parents. For this reason, child support is generally payable to the parent providing the ongoing care of the child. If child support were limited or withheld until access arrangements could be agreed or successful mediation sessions were attended, the parent providing the ongoing care may not be able to meet all the necessary financial obligations required to support the child.
When the care of a child has changes from one parent to another, the assessment should be updated to recognise the costs borne by the parent who provides ongoing daily care for the child.

In response to concerns regarding disputed care arrangements, the Family Assistance and Child Support Legislation Amendment (Protecting Children) Act 2018 (the Act) made amendments to the Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989 and the Child Support (Registration and Collection) Act 1988 to strengthen incentives to comply with court orders or participate in dispute resolution processes about care.

For court-ordered arrangements, the percentage of care used to determine the child support assessment can continue to be based on the order or agreement for up to 52 weeks from the date the care arrangements changed if the disputed care change occurs within the first year of the order. For older court orders, the child support assessment will continue for 26 weeks (previously 14 weeks) if the person with increased care does not take reasonable action to participate in family dispute resolution.

The policy aims to balance the day-to-day needs of the parent with actual care arrangements and the additional expenses they are incurring, with that of the other parent who has a right to seek to enforce a parenting order or other written agreement. The Government acknowledges that family law and child support are complex matters.

Other amendments included in the Act enable changes in circumstances to be more easily reflected in child support assessments, for example increasing the circumstances in which amended tax assessments can be accepted. It also allows binding child support agreements made before 1 July 2008, where at least one party did not receive independent legal advice, to be more easily set aside.
A further measure in the Act will ensure the same measures used to collect child support from paying parents can be used in the recovery of child support overpayments from receiving parents.
These amendments were made to ensure the child support scheme objectives meet community expectations.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Families and Social Services, Paul Fletcher MP (Petition No. EN0630)
Migration
Dear Mrs Wicks

Thank you for your letter of 13 August 2018 to the former Minister for Social Services, the Hon Dan Tehan MP, concerning the petition EN0634 to the House of Representatives. I am responding to your letter as the matter raised now falls within my portfolio responsibilities. I am sorry it has taken me so long to respond.

I would also like to thank the 72 signatories of this petition for the interest they have shown in the Social Services Legislation Amendment (Encouraging Self-sufficiency for Newly Arrived Migrants) Bill 2018 (the Bill).

The Bill introduces a measure announced in the 2017-18 Mid-Year Economic and Fiscal Outlook and subsequently extended in the 2018-19 Budget. Under this measure the Newly Arrived Resident's Period (NARWP) that currently applies to certain social security payments, such as Newstart Allowance, will increase from two to four years. A new four-year waiting period will also be introduced for family payments, including Family Tax Benefit.

The NARWP will continue to apply to migrants under the skilled and family streams of Australia's Migration Program. This recognises that these migrants are well placed to support themselves during the waiting period either through work or through family members already in Australia.

The Australian Government is also maintaining a number of key safeguards to ensure appropriate protections for potentially vulnerable migrants and those who find themselves in hardship for reasons beyond their control. This includes provisions for humanitarian migrants and their families and people who experience a substantial change of circumstances and are in financial hardship.
All permanent residents will continue to have access to other government funded payments and services including health care, education and child care subsidies.

This measure will ensure consistent rules are applied across the welfare payments system, and strikes a balance between promoting self-reliance for newly arrived migrants and providing appropriate safeguards for those in vulnerable circumstances.

The changes to the NARWP were announced to commence from 1 July 2018; however, legislation to implement the measure is currently before Parliament. The measure will commence once the legislation is passed. Updates on the progress of the legislation will be provided on my Department's website at www.dss.gov.au/living-in-australia-and-overseas/updates.

I understand the concern raised in the petition that people who apply for a permanent visa before the commencement of this measure but are not granted their visa until after commencement will be affected. It is common for policies across the whole of Government to change in the time between a visa application being lodged and granted. It is the responsibility of migrants to make informed decisions about the policy settings that may affect them before accepting a visa.

Current visa applicants have access to information about the changes so they can make informed decisions about how they will support themselves during the waiting period before accepting a permanent visa, if granted. This information including updates on the date of commencement, is provided on my Department's website at the above web address. This information is also accessible via the Department of Home Affairs and the Department of Human Services websites.

My Department has also developed a comprehensive communication strategy to inform existing and prospective migrants of the changes to the waiting period once the legislation passes. My Department is working closely with other government departments, key stakeholders and multicultural communication experts to ensure that existing and prospective visa applicants will have access to information on the new rules and, importantly, the exemptions available for vulnerable groups and how migrants can access these exemptions. The strategy includes culturally appropriate and translated materials, which will be distributed across a broad range of channels.
Thank you again for your letter. I appreciate the time the petition signatories have taken to bring this matter to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Families and Social Services, Paul Fletcher MP (Petition No. EN0634)
Child Abuse
Dear Mrs Wicks

Thank you for your letter dated 14 August 2018 to my predecessor, the Hon Dan Tehan MP, former Minister for Social Services, concerning the petition presented in the House of Representatives, EN0641 - Braxton's Law.

The Australian Government (the Government) recognises that all children and young people have the right to grow up in a safe and secure environment and is committed to improving the safety and wellbeing of Australian children in all circumstances.

State and territory governments have jurisdiction over child protection matters. Each jurisdiction has its own governing legislation, policies and practices dealing with children and young people experiencing, or at risk of, child abuse or neglect.

The Government is working in partnership with state and territory governments on child protection issues through the National Framework for Protecting Australia's Children 2009-2020 (National Framework), which focuses on addressing complex problems requiring joined-up, concentrated effort from Commonwealth and state and territory governments, and the non-government sector.

The National Principles for Child Safe Organisations (National Principles) is one of the key initiatives developed under the Third Action Plan of the National Framework, for endorsement by the Council of Australian Governments (COAG), to make institutions safe for children in all relevant sectors, including within the out-of-home care sector.

The National Principles were developed under the guidance and oversight of the Community Services Ministers across all jurisdictions and embed the child safe standards recommended by the Royal Commission into Institutional Responses to Child Sexual Abuse. Robust recruitment and pre-employment screening, ongoing supervision of staff as well as effective complaint handling mechanisms to address concerns about child safety, are included in the National Principles.

Once endorsed by COAG, the National Principles will provide a nationally consistent approach to cultivating organisational cultures that foster child safety and wellbeing across all sectors in Australia. These Principles are intended to promote consistency and a shared understanding across jurisdictions of the core elements of child safe organisations. While each jurisdiction may give effect to these core elements in different ways, the National Principles will assist with ensuring safer environments for children in institutional settings including in out-of-home care.

With regard to the proposed independent oversight body to address concerns about child safety to avoid child deaths, I am aware that a range of state and territory bodies already provide review or investigation of children's deaths including Attorneys-General, Ombudsmen, Coroners and child death review committees, as well as state and territory Inquiries. The New South Wales, Australian Capital Territory and Victorian governments have also introduced Reportable Conduct Scheme legislation to oversee how organisations prevent and respond to allegations of child abuse and misconduct. The establishment of further oversight mechanisms is a matter for state and territory governments in line with their statutory responsibility for child protection matters.

The Department of Social Services led the Commonwealth Government's response to the Senate Inquiry into Out of Home Care Report, released in September 2017. This response addressed all recommendations of the Inquiry Report, including the recommendation referred to in the petition. For all recommendations directed at COAG, the response emphasised the Commonwealth Government's commitment to bringing the Inquiry Report to the attention of state and territory governments through the Children and Families Secretaries group.
The full Government response is available at

https://www.aph.gov.au/Parliamentary_Business/Committees/Senate/Community_Affairs/Out_of_home_care under "Government Response". The response to recommendations directed at COAG, including recommendation 27, are at pages 4-12.
Thank you again for referring petition EN0641.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Families and Social Services, Paul Fletcher MP (Petition No. EN0641)
Electric Vehicles
Dear Mrs Wicks

Thank you for your letter of 13 August 2018 to the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Infrastructure, Transport and Regional Development, the Hon Michael McCormack MP, regarding Petition EN0648 - Ministerial Referral. Your letter was forwarded to me as I am the minister responsible for the matter you raised. I apologise for the delay in replying.
The petition calls for a change to the Motor Vehicle Standards Act 1989 (the Act) to enable motorised push/kick scooters with a power output of up to 250 watts to be used on public cycleways.

The Australian Government administers the Act, which requires that all new road vehicles comply with national vehicle standards known as the Australian Design Rules (ADRs), before they can be offered to the market for use in transport in Australia. The ADRs are mostly performance-based standards for vehicle safety, emission control (noxious gases and external noise) and anti-theft protection.

Under the Act, a machine is assessed as a road vehicle based on its technical characteristics and design purpose. These determine its performance capability, including whether it is capable of being, and/or intended to be, used on-road (including public roads), off-road, or for some special purpose.

In assessing a machine, the Act and ADRs specifically exempt unpowered or low-powered machines. In parallel with this, state and territory governments allow such machines to be used on roads, footpaths and cycleways without any requirement to meet further safety standards or to license the rider/operator. The longstanding limit in power output of 200 watts for these machines is based on the equivalent power output of a person riding a bicycle, which then minimises the risk of collisions and injuries when using roads and/or interacting with pedestrians or cyclists on footpaths and cycleways. Regarding the 10km/h limit referred to in the petition, this is a state and territory requirement placed on motorised wheelchairs rather than motorised push/kick scooters.

In late 2017, the Government determined a number of types of machines not to be road vehicles (through the Motor Vehicle Standards (Road Vehicles) Determination 2017). This provides further clarity and certainty and so reduces the burden on industry and the public seeking to import these machines. To this end, the Department of Infrastructure, Regional Development and Cities has placed revised explanatory material on its website. Further information can be found at www.infrastructure.gov.au/vehicles/imports/import options/orneao.aspx.

The interest in alternative vehicles by some segments of the Australian community poses a major challenge both to better accommodate vehicles that may have mobility and/or environmental benefits while not compromising on safety, as well as to provide a regulatory framework that can be understood by all, including consumers and enforcement agencies.

Infrastructure and transport ministers agreed under the National Road Safety Strategy 2011-2020 to investigate further regulation of speed and other safety features for alternative vehicles (for example, mobility scooters and power-assisted bicycles). In the lead up to this, the then New South Wales Roads and Traffic Authority coordinated a comprehensive review, hosting forums with wide-ranging interest groups. Through this, there was community support to extend the exemption in the ADRs from 200 watts up to 250 watts for machines that meet the major market standard European Committee for Standardization EN 15194:2009 or EN 15194:2009+A1:2011 Cycles - Electrically power assisted cycles - EPAC Bicycles; which includes construction and power limiting safety requirements. State and territory governments subsequently agreed to allow these machines to be used on Australia's footpaths and cycleways.

This reform was incorporated into the ADRs in 2012, with Austroads (the association of Australian and New Zealand road transport and traffic authorities and the Australian Local Government Association, providing information and advice to governments and promoting research in the Australasian road and road transport sectors) undertaking a further program of review regarding other low-powered machines, as part of a proposed national policy framework for alternative vehicles.

Following a number of focused projects by Austroads, the National Transport Commission (an independent statutory body that develops regulatory and operational reform of road, rail and intermodal transport) has now commenced a broad project to identify opportunities for new and innovative vehicles and mobility devices, including small automated vehicles. The Department is participating in this project and the Government will consider carefully any future recommendations on changes needed to the Act and/or ADRs regarding the use of low-powered machines (such as motorised push/kick scooters) on Australian roads, footpaths and cycleways.
Thank you for bringing your concerns to the Australian Government's attention and I trust this is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Minister to the Deputy Prime Minister, the Hon Andrew Broad MP (Petition No. EN0648)
Business
Dear Mrs Wicks

Thank you for your correspondence of 17 September 2018, originally directed to the Treasurer concerning Petition referral EN0651 - the application of the responsible lending obligations to businesses and commercial entities. As this matter falls within my portfolio responsibilities, your correspondence has been referred to me for response.
The Government has established a Royal Commission into the alleged misconduct of Australia's banks, superannuation and other financial services entities.

The Royal Commission has a broad remit to inquire into practices of financial services entities, including banks, insurers, superannuation, holders of Australian financial services licenses and intermediaries, such as mortgage brokers.

Additionally, the Royal Commission is examining the adequacy of the existing laws and policies of the Commonwealth relating to the provision of banking and related financial services. This includes the examination of the laws concerning the provision of credit and the responsible lending framework. The Royal Commission's Interim Report, released 28 September 2018, has sought submissions on whether the responsible lending obligations should be extended to small business and agricultural business lending.
Individuals are able to make a submission to the Royal Commission by visiting the following address: www.financialservices.royalcommission.gov.au/public-submissions/pages/default.aspx.
The Government will carefully consider the findings and recommendations of the Royal Commission in developing any further responsible lending obligations for the financial services sector.
I hope this information is of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Treasurer , the Hon Stuart Robert MP (Petition No. EN0651)
Parliament
Dear Mrs Wicks

Thank you for your letter dated 21 September 2018 to the Prime Minister, the Hon Scott Morrison MP, regarding a petition on Federal Parliamentarians' remuneration and work expenses (petition number EN0658). The Prime Minister has asked me to respond on his behalf
The petition called for the House of Representatives to implement pay scales and entitlements for Federal Parliamentarians equivalent and not greater than those of the hospitality industry.

Remuneration for Federal Parliamentarians is not determined by the Parliament. Their conditions are determined by the Remuneration Tribunal, an independent statutory authority established under the Remuneration Tribunal Act 1973. Over the 2013-2017 period, the Tribunal reduced both the quantum and frequency of its adjustments due to the environment of economic restraint, lower wage growth more broadly and the Government's Public Sector Workplace Bargaining Policy.
Responsibility for setting award wages and conditions, including penalty rates, for the hospitality industry also sits with an independent tribunal, the Fair Work Commission, not the Government.

Moreover, the Government has implemented the most comprehensive reforms to Federal Parliamentarians' work expenses in a generation to ensure the way parliamentarians spend public money meets the expectations of the Australian public.

Last year, the Government established the Independent Parliamentary Expenses Authority (IPEA), an independent statutory authority with advisory, reporting and auditing responsibilities for the work expenses of Federal Parliamentarians and their staff. Establishing an independent authority to be the watchdog and the provider of advice and rulings ensures that Australians can trust that their money is being spent appropriately.

In addition, the Government has ended access to the Life Gold Pass scheme (apart from former Prime Ministers and their spouses) which had previously provided limited free domestic travel for eligible former parliamentarians. Penalties are now imposed when a travel claim is made by a Federal Parliamentarian in excess of their entitlements; they are now compelled to only access public resources where it is for the dominant purpose of conducting parliamentary business; and parliamentarians are required by law to use public money efficiently, effectively and economically, consistent with the obligations on the proper use of public resources by Commonwealth officials.

Details of Federal Parliamentarians' expenses, including their travel costs, are now published periodically on the IPEA website, contributing to our Government's reforms to contribute to a more transparent system.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Minister to the Prime Minister, the Hon Steve Irons MP (Petition No. EN0658)
Australian Constitution
Dear Mrs Wicks

Thank you for your correspondence of 17 September 2018 concerning petition EN0664 on firearms and weapons for personal protection. Your correspondence has been referred to me as the Assistant Minister for Home Affairs as the matter falls within my portfolio responsibilities.

Firearms control in Australia is a shared responsibility between the Commonwealth and state and territory governments. The overarching framework for firearms control is outlined in the National Firearms Agreement (NFA), which was updated in February 2017. A copy of the NFA is attached for your convenience.
The NFA explicitly states, at paragraph 10, that 'personal protection is not a genuine reason for acquiring, possessing or using a firearm'.
The Australian Government is committed to upholding the NFA and encourages the states and territories to do likewise.
Thank you for bringing this petition to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Minister for Home Affairs, Senator the Hon Linda Reynolds CSC (Petition No. EN0664)
NATIONAL FIREARMS AGREEMENT
Council of Australian Governments
An agreement between
the Commonwealth of Australia and
the States and Territories, being:
o The State of New South Wales
o The State of Victoria
o The State of Queensland
o The State of Western Australia
o The State of South Australia
o The State of Tasmania
o The Australian Capital Territory
o The Northern Territory of Australia
OPENING STATEMENT
1. The National Firearms Agreement constitutes a national approach to the regulation of

firearms. The Agreement affirms that firearms possession and use is a privilege that is conditional on the overriding need to ensure public safety, and that public safety is improved by the safe and responsible possession, carriage, use, registration, storage and transfer of firearms.

2. This Agreement sets out minimum requirements in relation to the regulation of firearms. Nothing in this Agreement prevents jurisdictions from adopting additionalâincluding more restrictiveâregulations.

3. Having regard to the National Firearms Trafficking Policy Agreement, first agreed in 2002, jurisdictions agree to establish or maintain substantial penalties for the illegal possession of a firearm.
PROVISION TO MAINTAIN FUNDAMENTAL ASPECTS OF THE NATIONAL FIREARMS AGREEMENT

4. The Council of Australian Governments and its subordinate bodies will periodically consider emerging issues relating to this Agreement, including, for example, improvements and advancements in firearm technologies. Issues for consideration will be those which will ensure that the Agreement remains true to its fundamental aspects, being: the requirement for a genuine reason for possessing or using a firearm, the appropriate categorisation of firearms, the registration of firearms, firearms licensing (including fit and proper person requirements), the requirement for a permit to acquire each firearm, the safe and secure storage of firearms, the recording of firearms sales, and suitable firearms transaction practices.
RESTRICTIONS ON CERTAIN FIREARMS
5. The Commonwealth will restrict the importation of:
(a) all semi-automatic long arms and pump action shotguns, and all partsâincluding magazinesâfor such firearms, included in Licence Categories C and D
(b) magazines with a capacity greater than thirty for long arms and magazines with a capacity greater than twenty for handguns
(c) all handguns for sporting shooting purposes other than those which meet the prescribed characteristicsâincluding barrel length, magazine capacity and calibreâin paragraph 14(b) (i)

(d) handgun parts for sport shooting purposes (for example slides, barrels, receivers and frames) which could be used to assemble a prohibited handgun or convert a permitted handgun into a prohibited handgun.

6. Jurisdictions will ban the sale, resale, transfer, possession, manufacture and use of those semi-automatic long arms and pump action shotguns included in licence Category C and 0 other than in the following exceptional circumstances:
(a) military use
(b) police or other government purposes
(c) occupational categories of licence holders who have been licensed for a specified purpose, including
i. the extermination of animals
ii. film and theatrical armourers
iii. firearm dealers
iv. firearm manufacturers
v. additional occupational needs and other limited purposes as authorised by legislation or Ministerial discretion
(d) collectors
(e) in the case of Category C shotguns

i. members of the Australian Clay Target Association or clubs affiliated with the Australian Clay Target Association with a medical need to use a Category C shotgun due to a lack of strength or dexterity, or

ii. individuals who were on 15 November 1996 registered shooters with the Australian Clay Target Association and who, at that time, possessed a semi-automatic shotgun or pump action repeating shotgun for use in clay target events.

7. Jurisdictions will restrict the importation, possession and use of handguns for sporting purposes to individuals meeting recognised sporting shooter classifications in the Olympic and Commonwealth Games and for other accredited events that meet the conditions in paragraph 14(b) (i).
8. Jurisdictions will ban competitive shooting involving those long arms which are restricted from import, except for those individuals who meet the conditions in paragraph 13(b) (iii).
GENUINE REASONS AND NEED FOR ACQUIRING, POSSESSING OR USING A FIREARM
9. Individuals must demonstrate a genuine reason for acquiring, possessing or using a firearm. The genuine reasons and relevant qualifying statements are listed in paragraphs 13-23.
10. Personal protection is not a genuine reason for acquiring, possessing or using a firearm.
11. Over and above satisfaction of the "genuine reason" test, an applicant for a licence must demonstrate a genuine need for the particular type of firearm (excluding Category A firearms).
12. Only certain categories of firearms can be acquired, possessed or used under each genuine reason. Categories of firearms are listed in paragraphs 25-29.NATIONAL FIREARMS AGREEMENT
GENUINE REASONS
13. Sports shootersâlong arms

(a) Sports shooters must have a valid membership with an approved club (defined as clubs participating in shooting sports recognised in the charters of such major sporting events as the Commonwealth Games, Olympic Games or World Championships).
(b) Firearms permitted for acquisition, possession or use under this genuine reason are:
i. Category A
ii. Category B
iii. Category C shotguns, limited to

1 members of the Australian Clay Target Association or clubs affiliated with the Australian Clay Target Association with a medical need to use a Category C shotgun due to a lack of strength or dexterity, or

2 individuals who were on 15 November 1996 registered shooters with the Australian Clay Target Association and who, at that time, possessed a semi-automatic shotgun or pump action repeating shotgun for use in clay target events.
14. Sports shooters â handguns
(a) Sports shooters must have a valid membership with an approved club.

(b) Firearms permitted for acquisition, possession or use under this genuine reason are: Category H â the firearm must be designed or adapted for competition target shooting, or must have a barrel length of at least 120mm for a semi-automatic handgun or 100mm for a revolver or a single shot handgun. If the firearm is fitted with a firearm magazine or cylinder, it must have a capacity of not more than 10 rounds. The calibre of the firearm must not exceed .38" (with the exception of cases listed under paragraph 14(c)).

(c) Handguns with a calibre greater than .38" but no greater than .45" are permitted only where shooters are competing in the two accredited events known as Metallic Silhouette and Single (Western) Action.
15. Recreational shooters/hunters
(a) Recreational shooters/hunters must produce proof of permission from a landowner.
(b) Firearms permitted for acquisition, possession or use under this genuine reason are:
i. Category A
ii. Category B
16. Primary producers
(a) Primary producers must satisfy the licensing authority that there is a genuine need

for the use of the firearm which pertains to the applicant's occupation and which cannot be achieved by some other means. The application is to be approved by the Commissioner of the Police who may impose conditions as to the use of the firearms, including as to the geographical location of its use.
(b) Firearms permitted for acquisition, possession or use under this genuine reason are:
i. Category A
ii. Category B

iii. Category C â where the licensing authority is satisfied that there is a genuine need for the use of the firearm which cannot be achieved by some other means (including the use of Category A or B firearms). Primary producers are limited to one Category C shotgun and one Category C rifle

iv. Category D â where the licensing authority is satisfied that there is a genuine need for the use of a Category D firearm for the purposes of controlling vertebrate pest animals in the course of primary production activities. Jurisdictions may require individuals to meet additional requirements (for example, safety training and marksmanship) to qualify for Category D acquisition, possession or use, or to establish certain facts (for example, lack of other pest control options) in order to demonstrate need.
17. Occupational requirement (other rural purposes and professional shooters for nominated purposes)

(a) Persons with an occupational interest must satisfy the licensing authority that there is a genuine need for the use of the firearm which pertains to the applicant's occupation and which cannot be achieved by some other means. The application is to be approved by the Commissioner of the Police who may impose conditions as to the use of the firearms, including as to the geographical location of its use.
(b) Firearms permitted for acquisition, possession or use under this genuine reason are:
i. Category A
ii. Category B
18. Security employees
(a) Firearms permitted for acquisition, possession or use under this genuine reason are:
i. Category A
ii. Category H
19. Collectors
(a) Collectors will be regulated by means of a licence and permit system which tests their bona fides.
(b) Firearms permitted for acquisition and possession under this genuine reason are:
i. Category A â must be rendered temporarily inoperable
ii. Category B â must be rendered temporarily inoperable
iii. Category C â must be rendered temporarily inoperable
iv. Category D â must be rendered permanently inoperable
v. Category H â must be rendered temporarily inoperable

(c) For the purposes of handguns, jurisdictions agree that they will accredit historical societies. Historical societies are required to notify police of a member's expulsion as well as the reasons for expulsion. Accredited historical societies will be indemnified from civil or legal liability where they notify police in good faith of their belief that a person is unfit to hold a collector's licence.
20. Heirlooms

(a) Jurisdictions agree that where the owner of an heirloom firearm is unable to establish a genuine reason for possession of that firearm and/or does not qualify for a collector's licence, jurisdictions may issue the heirloom owner with a special category of licence. The requirements of that heirloom licence must be that:
i. before the licence is issued, the owner provides sufficient proof of inheritance of the heirloom
ii. the licence apply only to a single gun, or a matched pair or set
iii. all heirloom firearms be rendered permanently inoperable
iv. the licence not authorise the discharge of the heirloom firearm or firearms in any circumstance.
21. Firearm dealers
(a) Jurisdictions must have regulations addressing firearm dealers.
22. Firearm manufacturers
(a) Jurisdictions must have regulations addressing firearm manufacturers.
23. Film and/or theatrical armourers
(a) Jurisdictions must have regulations addressing film and theatrical armourers.
CATEGORIES OF FIREARMS
24. The following categories are to be used in the licensing of firearms.
25. Licence Category A
(a) Air rifles
(b) Rimfire rifles (excluding semi-automatic)
(c) Shotguns (other than semi-automatic, pump action or lever action)
(d) Rimfire rifle/shotgun combinations
26. Licence Category B
(a) Muzzle-loading firearms
(b) Single shot, double barrel and repeating centrefire rifles
(c) Centrefire rifle/shotgun combinations
(d) Lever action shotguns with a magazine capacity no greater than five rounds
27. Licence Category C
(a) Semi-automatic rimfire rifles with a magazine capacity no greater than 10 rounds
(b) Semi-automatic and pump action shotguns with a magazine capacity no greater than five rounds
28. Licence Category D
(a) Semi-automatic centrefire rifles designed or adapted for military purposes or a firearm which substantially duplicates those rifles in design, function or appearance
(b) Non-military style self-loading centrefire rifles
(c) Semi-automatic, pump action and lever action shotguns with a magazine capacity greater than five rounds
(d) Semi-automatic rimfire rifles with a magazine capacity greater than 10 rounds 29. Licence Category H
(a) All handguns, including air pistols
NATIONWIDE REGISTRATION

30. Jurisdictions agree to the nationwide registration of all firearms. Jurisdictions will record sufficient information to be able to uniquely identify each firearm, including details prescribed by the national information-sharing hub.
31. Jurisdictions agree to store registrations on a system which is able to share information with the national information-sharing hub.
LICENSING
32. Jurisdictions agree to maintain a uniform system of testing applicants for firearms licences.
33. In addition to the demonstration of genuine reason, a licence applicant must be required to:
(a) be aged 18 or over
(b) be a fit and proper person
(c) be able to prove identity through a 100 point system requiring a passport or multiple types of identification
(d) undertake adequate safety training (see paragraph 35).
34. A licence must:
(a) bear a photograph of the licensee
(b) be endorsed with the category of the firearm
(c) be issued after a waiting period of not less than 28 days
(d) be issued for a period of no more than five years
(e) contain a reminder of safe storage responsibilities

(f) be issued subject to undertakings to comply with storage requirements, to provide details of proposed storage provisions at the time of licensing, and to submit to a mutually arranged (with due recognition of privacy) inspection by licensing authorities of storage facilities.
35. Requisite training
(a) Jurisdictions agree that first time licence applicants must complete an accredited course in safety training for firearms. The course must be:
i. comprehensive and standardised across Australia for all licence categories

ii. subject to accreditation of the course syllabus, by an appropriate authority, and a system of accredited instructors to bring prospective licensees to the required standard with a focus on firearms law, firearms safety and firearms competency
iii. monitored as to content of courses and the skills of instructors by firearms regulatory authorities.
(b) Jurisdictions agree to have a separate specialised training course for individuals employed by the security industry.
36. Sports shooters â handguns
(a) Sports shooters must have a valid membership with an approved club.
i. Clubs will have the power to request a police check on a person prior to accepting them as a member of a club.
ii. A person applying to join a club must provide that club with two character references from people they have known for at least two years.
iii. Clubs must endorse a member's application to acquire a handgun. In endorsing the application, clubs should:
1 confirm that the licensee has adequate storage arrangements in place
2 specify for which competition shooting discipline the handgun is required.

iv. To prevent 'club shopping', a person wishing to join a club must provide to that club details of any other shooting clubs to which they belong and details of the firearms they possess. In addition, clubs are empowered to request information from licensing authorities on a member's or applicant's possession of handguns and their membership of other clubs.
v. Shooting clubs are required to provide licensing authorities with an audited annual report providing member details, firearms possessed, and participation rates.

(b) Jurisdictions agree to a system for graduated access to handguns for legitimate sporting shooters based on training, experience and event participation. The system will be based on graduated access to handguns over a period of 12 months and will incorporate the following principles:
i. a person is required to obtain a police check and submit this with their application to join a shooting club
ii. during the first six months a person will not be permitted to own a handgun, must satisfactorily complete a firearm safety training course and meet minimum participation rates

iii. if a club certifies that a person has satisfactorily complied with the conditions attached to the first six months' probation, then during the second six months a person will only be permitted to own one .22" calibre rimfire pistol and one .177" air pistol, or one centrefire pistol and one .177" calibre air pistol.

(c) After the initial period of 12 months, acquisition of additional handguns is subject to demonstration of genuine need, confirmation that the licensee has adequate storage arrangements in place, and specification of the competition shooting discipline for which the handgun is required.
37. Collectors

(a) The licensing process must include a provision for an initial inspection of storage facilities and for subsequent mutually arranged inspections. All such inspections will be subject to the recognition of the individual's right to privacy. The onus of defining 'bona fide firearms collector' rests with each State and Territory. However, the following principles must underpin the regulation of bona fide firearms collectors:
i. the firearms which are the subject of the collection should be of or above a defined age

ii. firearms in a collection which have been manufactured after 1 January 1946 must be rendered inoperable (whether or not they are otherwise only required to be rendered temporarily inoperable according to paragraph 19(b))
iii. collectors may not possess ammunition for a collection firearm
iv. any attempt to restore firearms in the collection to usable condition should be regarded as a serious offence and subject to severe penalties
v. all operating firearms which are owned by the collector under separate licensing arrangements should be subject to the same level of regulation as any other operating firearm
vi. for the purposes of the collection of Category H firearms, genuine historical collectors must
1 be a member of a state or territory accredited historical firearm collectors society
2 have their licence application endorsed by an accredited historical firearms collectors society
3 comply with strict storage requirements
4 display a commitment as a student of arms in order to collect or retain post-1946 handguns.
38. Grounds for licence refusal or cancellation and seizure of firearms

(a) Jurisdictions agree to set out in legislation the circumstances in which licence applications (including renewals) are to be refused, licences are to be cancelled, or firearms are to be seized. The following minimum standards must apply:

i. general reasons â not of good character, conviction for an offence involving violence within the past five years, unsafe storage, contravention of firearms law, where it can be shown that the loss or theft of a firearm was due to negligence or fraud on the part of the licensee, no longer has a genuine reason, not in public interest due to (defined) circumstances, not notifying of change of address, or licence obtained by deception

ii. specific reasons â where applicant/licence holder has been the subject of an Apprehended Violence Order, Domestic Violence Order, restraining order or conviction for assault with a weapon/aggravated assault within the past five years
iii. mental or physical fitness â reliable evidence of a mental or physical condition which would render the applicant unsuitable for acquiring, possessing or using a firearm.
(b) In regard to 38(a) (iii), a balance is to be struck between the rights of the individual
to privacy and fair treatment, and the responsibility of authoritiesâon behalf of the community--to prevent danger to the individual and the wider community.
(c) Jurisdictions may impose appropriate penalties, in addition to licence cancellation or
seizure of firearms, for failure to comply with security and storage conditions.
(d) Jurisdictions will establish an appeal process for refusal of a licence application or cancellation of a licence.
(e) Specifically in relation to the cancellation of Category H licences, jurisdictions agree:
i. to introduce or maintain laws allowing the Commissioner of Police to refuse
and revoke handgun licences and applications on the basis of criminal intelligence or any other relevant information with consideration to appropriate safeguards including expert advice
ii. that members of approved shooting clubs be required to attend a minimum
number of shooting events offered by the club, and that failure to meet the minimum participation level will make a person liable to have their licence revoked

iii. that sporting shooters meet minimum participation rates annually, specifically that a sports shooter must participate in a minimum number of six club organised competitive shooting matches, and for each different type of handgun owned for different events the sporting shooter must undertake at least four club organised shoots

iv. that clubs must notify licensing authorities of concerns about club members' suitability to hold a licence, and indemnify clubs for providing such information to licensing authorities about the suitability of club members to hold a licence. In particular, jurisdictions will
1 require sporting shooting clubs to report to police their concerns that a person may pose a danger if in possession of a handgun
2 require sporting shooting clubs to notify police of a member's expulsion and the reasons for expulsion
3 indemnify sporting shooting clubs from civil or legal liability if they notify police in good faith of matters identified in paragraphs 38(e) (iv) (1) and 38(e) (iv) (2)
4 require sporting shooting clubs to ensure that a person whose licence has been revoked or suspended does not use a handgun at the sporting club

v. to support the operation of the fit and proper person test throughout the life of the licence allowing for the licensing authorities' revocation of a person's licence and seizure of handguns on grounds of not being a fit and proper person at any time
vi. to require suspension/cancellation of licences and seizure of firearms immediately upon the issue of an Apprehended Violence Order or Domestic Violence Order to a firearm licence holder.
39. Medical authorities reporting model

(a) Jurisdictions agree that reporting provisions for medical authorities be improved or maintained by indemnifying medical authorities from civil or criminal liability for reporting in good faith to police their concerns that a person may pose a danger if in possession of a firearm or applying for a firearm licence. This is providing that 'medical authorities' include medical practitioners, nurses, social workers, psychiatrists, psychologists and professional counsellors.
40. Mutual recognition
(a) Jurisdictions will recognise visiting licensees for the following firearms and purposes:
i. Category A and B â sporting, recreational hunting and any other lawful purpose
ii. Category C â sporting and any other lawful purpose
iii. Category H â sporting and any other lawful purpose
(b) Category D and other categories of firearms not listed in this Agreement are not subject to mutual recognition provisions.
(c) Where an individual is moving permanently to a new jurisdiction, that jurisdiction will recognise:
i. for a period no more than three months, a Category A or B licence issued in another jurisdiction
ii. for a period no more than seven days, a Category C, 0 or H licence issued in another jurisdiction.
PERMIT TO ACQUIRE
41. Jurisdictions agree that a separate permit is required for the acquisition of every firearm.

42. Jurisdictions agree that each applicant must establish, to the satisfaction of the licensing authority, that they have a genuine need for acquiring, possessing or using the firearm of the nominated type (excluding Category A firearms).

43. Jurisdictions agree that the issuing of a permit must be subject to a waiting period of at least 28 days to enable appropriate checks to be made on licensees in order to ascertain whether circumstances have occurred since the issuing of the original licence which would render the licensee unsuitable to possess the firearm or which would render the licensee ineligible for that type of firearm.
STORAGE
44. Jurisdictions agree that firearms and ammunition must be stored in secure conditions as follows:

(a) it must be a precondition to the issuing of a new firearms licence (and on each renewal of licence in respect of existing licence holders) that the licensing authority be satisfied as to the proposed storage and security arrangements

(b) legislation must have the effect of making failure to store firearms in the manner required an offence as well as a matter that will lead to the cancellation of the licence and the confiscation of all firearms

(c) clear and specific measures must be indicated in legislation for the storage of firearms so that those who possess firearms know their obligations. The following minimum basic standards must apply:

i. Licence Category A and B â storage in a locked receptacle constructed of either hard wood or steel with a thickness to ensure it is not easily penetrable. If the weight is less than 150 kilograms, the receptacle shall be fixed to the frame of the floor or wall so as to prevent easy removal. The locks fitted to these receptacles must be of sturdy construction
ii. Licence Category C, D and H â storage in a locked, steel safe with a thickness to ensure it is not easily penetrable, bolted to the structure of a building
iii. all ammunition must be stored in locked containers separate from any firearms

(d) should individuals possessing a firearm wish to store firearms through measures other than those indicated in legislation, they must have the burden of persuading the firearms regulatory authority that they can provide the level of security not less than that required by the relevant approved practices

(e) in order to provide for the safekeeping of firearms when they are temporarily away from their usual place of storage, legislation must include a statement that the holder of the licence "must take reasonable care to ensure that the firearm is not lost or stolen and must take reasonable care to ensure that the firearm does not fall into the hands of an unauthorised person"

(f) the firearms safety bookletâwhich is to be distributed to all new licence applicants prior to attending a course of instructionâmust also feature clear and precise information on the obligations of firearms storage

(g) security at gun dealer premises must require the dealer meeting such additional requirements as the firearms regulatory authority deems appropriate having regard to the type of activity of the dealer

(h) where approval has been given for the possession or use of a firearm for a limited purpose, such as film production, the person authorised must meet such requirements as the firearms regulatory authority deems appropriate having regard to the type of activity for which possession has been authorised.
45. Jurisdictions should consider imposing greater storage requirements where multiple firearms are kept on the same property.

46. Jurisdictions agree to periodically consider the adequacy of their educational literature on storage to ensure that it emphasises the risk of firearms theft and the legislated requirements for safe storage, and that it highlights compliance monitoring activities and the jurisdiction's rigorous prosecution policy for non-compliance.

47. Jurisdictions must include a declaration in all licence/permit/renewal application forms which requires the applicant to state that they understand the firearm storage and security requirements as required by legislation.
48. Jurisdictions must have a strategic inspection and audit program for storage requirements.
49. Security industry storage
(a) Jurisdictions agree that the following minimum storage requirements represent an appropriate standard for storage of firearms used in the security industry:
i. up to five handguns
1 metal safe to be securely fastened to solid floor or wall by internal/hidden bolts and hidden within premises
2 individual disabling locks such as barrel or trigger locks to be fitted to the firearm when stored
ii. six to fifteen handguns
1 safes to be a minimum weight of 150kg
2 safes to be secured to or within brick or concrete walls and floors
3 premises to be fully intruder alarmed, monitored by a graded control room with back-to-base polling via a secure line (or, if unavailable due to remoteness, with radio or GSM backup)
4 panic switches/duress facility to be installed in the premises
iii. over fifteen handguns
1 safes to be a minimum weight of 500kg, with dual key locks
2 safes to be secured to or within brick or concrete walls and floors
3 premises to be fully intruder alarmed, monitored by a graded control room with back-to-base polling via a secure line (or, if unavailable due to remoteness, with radio or GSM backup)
4 panic switches/duress facility to be installed in the premises
5 vaults, control rooms, safes, perimeter and internal premises to maintain 24-hour monitoring and recording by CCTV, which is secured and inaccessible.

50. Jurisdictions may adopt the above standards either by way of legislative requirement or by introducing the standards as guidelines which provide Police Commissioners with limited flexibility for special or unique circumstances.
51.. There should be at least one annual inspection of firearms and firearms storage facilities used in the security industry.
RECORDING OF SALES
52. All firearms sales are to be conducted only by or through a licenced firearms dealer.
53. Jurisdictions agree to the following principles to underpin firearms dealer recording of firearms transactions:
(a) firearms dealers are obliged under penalty to ensure that purchasers are appropriately licenced for the firearm being purchased

(b) firearms dealers are required to record and maintain details (type, make, calibre and serial number) of each weapon purchased or sold against the identity (name, address and licence number) of the seller or the purchaser
(c) firearms dealers are required to provide records to the national register of firearms through the State or Territory licensing authority

(d) police personnel investigating a crime or checking the compliance of licenced gun dealers with recording responsibilities should have the right to inspect the records of licenced gun dealers without the need to give notice to the licensee

(e) jurisdictions may put in place alternate options for individuals living in remote locations where firearms dealers are not readily available (it may be possible, for instance, to authorise local police officers to certify sales/purchases in such circumstances).

54. Jurisdictions will legislate to allow the sale of ammunition only for those firearms for which the purchaser is licenced, and impose limits on the quantity of ammunition that may be purchased in a given period.
55. On the purchase of ammunition, the relevant licence must be produced.

56. Jurisdictions should consider requiring dealers to provide their register of transactions to a relevant authority once that dealer's licence is no longer valid. This should occur within an appropriate timeframe after the licence has become invalid.
SALE AND TRANSPORT OF FIREARMS
57. Jurisdictions will introduce or maintain legislation to ensure that, within their own borders:
(a) mail order arrangements (irrespective of how those orders were placed, for example via the telephone or Internet) will apply strictly on a licenced firearm dealer to licenced firearm dealer basis
(b) advertisement of firearms for sale
i. be prohibited unless the sale is conducted by or through a licenced firearms dealer
ii. list the licence number of the licensed firearms dealer and the owner selling the firearms, and include the serial number by which the firearms are registered
(c) the movement of firearms covered by Licence Categories C, D and H must be in
